newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African Left faces "painful" decisions -Shilowa.
newsitem.headline: S.African Left faces "painful" decisions -Shilowa.

text.p: South Africa's communist-labour partners faced painful decisions over their alliance with the ruling African National Congress, union leader Sam Shilowa said on Thursday.
Shilowa, general secretary of the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu), said in a speech to the national congress of the National Union of Metalworkers:

"One painful question has to be answered by Cosatu and the South African Communist Party (SACP) -- how do the two organisations which are not in opposition to the ANC play a role in transformation in a way which does not take away our independence?"
Shilowa said the three groups needed to redefine their alliance "to suit current times".
The three groups formed a formal alliance ahead of South Africa's first all-race election in 1994 but since then differences have arisen over such issues as privatisation.
Shilowa said labour needed to develop its own policy and mobilise behind it. "The key is to say, as a federation, we are going to be proactive in the development of policy," he said.
On privatisation, Shilowa repeated Cosatu's stance that "apartheid" state assets should be sold off.
"What we must be engaged in, is the restructuring of state assets away from what apartheid wanted to what we want," he said.
